title: Implement EV certificate verification for Linux.

sentences.text: We need to implement EV (extended validation) certificate verification (the X509Certificate::IsEV method) for Linux.
EV certificate verification is just a special case of verifying a certificate to a certificate policy.
(No comment was entered for this change.)
I think we need to implement certificate repository/db for linux before implementing EV certificate.
Actually, X509Certificate::Verify() is still not implemented.
I believe mozilla has cert db in its code.
I guess chromium/windows uses system cert db, but there is no such thing in linux now (we may use ca-certificates on debian derived distro, but might not be available on other distro).
Is there any plan for it?
NSS stores its built-in root CA certificates in the shared
library libnssckbi.so, which is equivalent to Debian's
sufficient for verifying certificates, including EV certificates.
We need to work with the Mozilla/NSS developers to define
system NSS cert db for Linux.
We will need that for two
- To allow users to add root CA certificates
Then, I'll work on implementing verifying certificates on linux using libnssckbi.so as starting point.
Does anyone already work on it?
I assigned the bug to you.
Please ask me if you have any NSS questions.
For EV certificate verification (X509Certificate::IsEV()), you can use the Firefox code as sample code:
needs a lot of code to call CERT_PKIXVerifyCert.
For X509Certificate::Verify(), the goal is to allow us to move certificate verification off the IO thread.
Right now we ask NSS's SSL library to verify the certificate.
but the drawback is that certificate is verified on the IO
Certificate verification is like getaddrinfo in that it needs to do network IO to check certificate revocation.
So it is better to move it off the IO thread (IO thread should not block).

For X509Certificate::Verify(), it is called in CertVerifier, which runs own thread to call X509Certificate::Verify(), so I think it's already off the IO thread and don't need to run another thread to verify certificate in X509Certificate::Verify(), right?
When you implement X509Certificate::Verify(), you don't need to worry about threading.
When X509Certificate::Verify() is implemented, we just need to change ssl_client_socket_nss.cc as follows:
This essentially tells NSS to not verify the certificate.
2. After the SSL handshake is finished, use CertVerifier to
(No comment was entered for this change.)

The following revision refers to this bug:
Use CERT_PKIXVerifyCert() with CRL to verify certificate.
It was not enough size if we use
or https://www.thawte.com/ would die by SIGSEGV.
recursively, so if there are some long PKIX_Lists, it
consumes stack a lot and dies by stack overflow.
Note that X509Certificate::Verify isn't used in SSLClientSocketNSS yet.
The following revision refers to this bug:
Detach verify thread from NSPR on linux.
The threads in our thread pool terminate after we have called PR_Cleanup.
Unless we detach them from NSPR, if we use
CertVerifier, net_unittests dies with segfault on shutdown.
TEST=net_unittests passes with code that uses CertVerifier.
The following revision refers to this bug:
Remember the intermediate CA certs if the server sends them to us.
The following revision refers to this bug:
The following revision refers to this bug:
Add LOAD_VERIFY_EV_CERT in net load loag.
We'd like to run EV cert verification in cert verifier's context, but EV cert verification is expensive and it is only relevant to main frame.
So, pass the LOAD_VERIFY_EV_CERT flag when the resource is main frame to request EV cert verification.
(No comment was entered for this change.)
What's the status of this bug?
Are you still working on it?
Yes, ukai is still working on this.
I believe the remaining work is to set up OCSP.
ukai's work on OCSP has been blocked by my two-week vacation earlier this month.
OCSP is an HTTP-based protocol, so there are some challenging problems in using our network stack to do OCSP.
Does that mean EV doesn't work on Windows either?
I'm trying to understand how to  prioritize this wrt a beta release.
On Windows, the system crypto library
(CryptoAPI) uses WinHTTP internally to do OCSP.
we need to configure NSS to do OCSP using our network stack
because the built-in HTTP client in NSS doesn't support proxies.
(No comment was entered for this change.)
The following revision refers to this bug:
Factor out PKIXVerifyCert function from Verify and share it with IsEV.
TEST=EV info shown on omnibar for https://www.thawte.com/, but not on https://bugs.webkit.org/
The following revision refers to this bug:
Fix build break with uninitialized variable 'ev_policy_tag'.
Fix some last nits in codereview.chromium.org/119026
The following revision refers to this bug:
Use strict revocation flags only for EV verification.
should not say the cert is revoked.
Anymore updates on this, still having problems?
thank you for taking care of this so quickly.
The following revision refers to this bug:
Address Alexei Volkov's comments on http://codereview.chromium.org/119026.
The following revision refers to this bug:
Disable OCSP until we have fixed the crash in OCSP code.
As a result our EV checks must fail because EV requires revocation checking.
TEST=Visit EV websites such as https://www.paypal.com/ and
Chromium must not show the EV status because it is not doing OCSP checks.
The following revision refers to this bug:
Try to fix crash in OCSP handlers.
Make sure OCSPRequestSession::Core is cancelled when OCSPRequestSession is deleted as URLFetcher does.
The following revision refers to this bug:
Merge 23696 - Try to fix crash in OCSP handlers.
Make sure OCSPRequestSession::Core is cancelled when OCSPRequestSession is deleted as URLFetcher does.
The following revision refers to this bug:
Fix leaks of (encoded) certificate extensions returned by
They can be freed as soon as they
The following revision refers to this bug:
Add code for enabling or disabling CRLs and OCSP correctly.
Previously we varied the number of elements in the method_flags array to enable/disable OCSP.
It turns out that's the wrong way.
Between CRLs and OCSP, we prefer OCSP.
Rearranging bugs to eliminate LinuxBeta label.
Demoting bugs that wouldn't block a beta release.
Would the following SSL certificates errors fall under this issue?
linux/build/src/chrome/browser/profile.cc(1013)] Not implemented reached in void  ProfileImpl::CreatePasswordStore()
implemented reached in static bool Encryptor::EncryptString(const std::string&,  std::string*)
I can otherwise enter a new issue.
fix.kowalski: yes, please enter a new issue.
URLs that cause CERT_PKIXVerifyCert to fail with error -8052.
